38556067.review:
I used to be into creating art of all kinds, but as life gets more complicated with a spouse, children, mortgage payments, etc., those sorts of things take a back seat unless you're doing it professionally.  Then something like Google's Tilt Brush comes along - a new tool in a new medium.  I didn't use it long, but I think long enough to realize the potential and some of the limitations.

Firstly, I'm sure a professional artist could do some amazing things with this software, but at the same time I'd say that the toolset is rather limited too - I'd like to see some Photoshop like tools included, masking, custom brushes, animation etc. and to my knowledge, nothing like that is included.  There are several indie developed apps on the market however looking to fill that very gap - and I picked up a few of those too.

The tools that they do give you can stimulate your imagination and in VR, with the ability to manipulate things from literally any angle and almost at any size, those tools can be powerful.  I wish they included an in-game gallery (maybe they do), so you wouldn't have to leave VR in order to view other's work - imagine opening someone else's art in a window in your creative space, or an actual picture for reference.  Sadly, you can't, but maybe some indie dev will figure it out.

With the price at $10, I'd say pick this title up if you have ANY interest in art or if you have children.

38127578.review:
Last July, I went to the first stop of the HTC Vive Live truck tour in San Diego. I expected to try out a virtual reality headset and either be unimpressed or think it was kind of cool. Then they loaded up Tilt Brush as my second demo and I could paint and actually see depth as I painted in three dimensions. This was a huge deal to me as I can't see 3D in movies or in those magic frame pictures that require you to be able to see 3D to appreciate.

I drew some flowers that day and signed a letter E for the first initial of my name.

Six months later I got to draw a purple monster that started out as a hut and ended up looking like a Pac-Man ghost in front of Skillman and Hackett at the Steam VR Developer Showcase. It was a pivotal moment in my life where I could thank the creators personally for one of the most remarkable art applications available on the market.

Despite the sappy emotional story, I encourage everyone at any age to pick up the Vive controllers and create something in Tilt Brush. I can't wait to see what fellow Vive owners and their friends come up with now that it is commercially available!

34838710.review: This is definitly one of the best uses for VR to date. It isnt a game, and there isnt any skill involved (although there is a pictionary style game you can play with friends). It is purely an outlet for creativity. The brushes and effects are perfect and allow you to create anything you can imagine. The learning curve for the controls takes all of 30 minutes, with most of that spent going through all the different brush options. The ability to instantly scale a sculpture (scene?) will often leave you speechless as your small sculpture becomes an environment around you. There are soo many nuances that the developers put in that make this one of the most (if not THE most) polished experiences available for VR.  Put on a good album and find the perfect way to unwind as it is guaranteed to lower your heartrate and make you smile.  10/10

Tilt Brush is by far one of my favorite ways to unwind and destress besides enjoying the devils lettuce on occasion but eventually I'm sure those two will one day meld into a perfect bliss for another time.

Whether you're an artist, an aspiring artist, or just someone who like to occasionally doodle then this is for you. Just YOU though! Don't share it with your kids they didn't clean their rooms anyway and you know it! Messy little bas.....

Tilt Brush lets you create a 3D canvas where you can paint in the world you stand in. You can totally go all Bob Ross up in the virtual realm and have an infinite amount of all the happy trees and happy little bushes you want!

You don't even have to be good at drawing either as there's always the option of tracing your subject and just recreating what someone else did but in the virtual realtiy.

Want proof?

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bAnosTyzuIU&list=PLXV5w8136lsqTZ4XsA15rOUpL2mf9zLtT&index=9

Jessica Rabbit took 3 days to get done but I traced and colored her in 3D while keeping her 2D.

Or if you a guy and there's a high probablity you are there's always the option of just drawing boobs. And let's face it that's always a win.

Buy it already! Enough said.

VR painting is like sculpting with acrylics. It can be wonky, frustrating, and disheartening when your final painting looks 1/100th as good as what you could do with a proper stylus and better brushes, but there's something amazing about being able to paint a 3D tree under the milky way in your living room. Tilt Brush makes me feel like a child and paint like one, and the former is totally worth the latter. 

This is an absolute must-buy if you've ever been a doodler or want a meditative VR experience. $20 is the perfect price point for it. 

However, don't buy this if you want the Photoshop of VR. This is the ArtRage of VR.

31077953.review:
[b]Tilt Brush不算一款游戏；更多算是一款绘图软件 [strike]steam的分类也的确是软件分类[/strike][/b]
[/i]三维作图的确是挺有意思的；VR也应该更多的作为一个工具；而不单单只是一个游戏设备；希望这也是以后VR的发展方向吧；
不过作为玩家这款软件也是更多的当作一款游戏来看待
[list]
    [*]这款软件你可以当作VR版的windows自带绘图工具来看待；
    [*]游戏默认左手柄可以进行各项设置(各类设置、绘图工具、颜色等等）
    [*]右手柄作为画笔；可以进行三位作画
    [*]游戏可以更换大小比例作画；如画好小花园之后放大；你能漫步其中
[/list]

这款游戏让我想起了，幼时的涂鸦游戏；现在有时回想简单的游戏也能带来不少的快乐梦想，一味追求复杂丰富的游戏性有时也会迷了双眼。
看见软件的宣传片；有一种说不明的喜悦兴奋，我有太多想画的东西；我愿意花费时间画好一套盔甲放大后穿上，画好一间房间放大后住进去；或者画一条龙
VR是实现梦想的东西；这款游戏激发了我童年的想象力；他能让你童年在纸上的涂鸦更加真实更加生动；就好像你的梦成真的了一样；如果说这款软件作为一款游戏所带来的最为本质的快乐。童年的梦一直沉睡在血液中；难以抑制看见宣传时来自血脉的兴奋。
这款软件呢；如果说最为一款绘图软件来看；只能说算是一个雏形测试版诸如此类；实际用处并不算太大
[h1][b]【推荐】[/b][/h1]

[i]以上仅为个人观点；感谢您花费宝贵的时间阅读[/i]

28275806.review:
To create in VR- what an experience!  You can paint a little igloo, zoom it up around yourself, walk in and paint a fire... zoom into the fire and paint some tiny flame golems having a party!  And join them!  It's amazing.

As a human looking at this new experience, it's ground breaking.  The visual is stunning.  The possiblities endless. 

As a professional artist looking for a serious tool to create in frequently, I'm left a bit hungry.  I'd love to see some 3d brushes, besides the flat 2d brushes in 3d space.  Sphere/blob brushes so one can sculpt, instead of creating a sphere out of rough "tape-like strokes".  Layers are a must too... to hide/show, move, scale, etc.  Taking a few notes from Oculus Quill (and all other creative apps).  

I really dig how Tilt Brush handles lighting... painting with light and being able to adjust the environtment/lighting.  3D objects actually take on form shadows (unlike Quill's 2D flat cell shading).  

Overall, I'd highly recommend Tilt Brush and I look forward to future developments that expand the array of possiblities.

27754427.review:
This show the *potential* of VR apps. I really wish it had grouping or layers, in the style of standard vector- or photo-editing software. I want to create a thing and then be able to move or scale it. As it stands, each single stroke is a distinct object. There is a basic Undo action, but no way to group strokes, name the group, or do anything more advanced (toggle visibilty, move, resize, copy/replicate).

There's a very nice screen-capture capability, too. You can take still images, 5-second predefined GIFs which shake back and forth to convey the depth of 3D, or capture your own video recording, short or long. This is a really nice way to get a sort of screen-grab of what the VR space is like, to post or share.

Knowing how Google tends to create good demo apps and kill off great, long-standing projects, I have no expectations they're going to continue iterating on this app. But this right here is VR 1.0: 3-5 years from now, there will be a plethora of these sorts of content-creation tools. The depth and complexity will sky-rocket. Tilt Brush is the Windows Paint of VR, and I'm ready for the Adobe Photoshop of VR. But right here, right now, this is as good as it gets.

Also, in the intro video on the Steam page, does anyone else worry that the woman at the beginning is going to hit her shin on that coffee table? Amiright??

26724352.review:
This is by far one of the most mind-blowing VR experiences, and Tilt Brush is actually what motivated me to make the not-so-small  jump from to the Vive from the Samsung Gear. 
Painting around you, in 3D space, is surreal. The controls are super intuitive and easy to use. Being able to load other people's drawings from the internet showcase is really helpful for getting ideas on techniques and seeing what can be done with the tools available. The ability to shrink and expand the scene is super cool for creating things in scale - cover vast distances rapidly while zoomed out and then zoom it in to be able to walk around your suddenly huge creation and add smaller detail. The animated brushes are super fun and stunning to use. The in-game video camera and gif maker is really cool too, for sharing online.

I am really hoping they develop it further, as it does have a few shortcomings- lack of 3D brushes (just wire and disco) is a bit disappointing for painting in a 3D space, as you are restricted to trying to paint 3D things with 2D brushes. The colors of paint in different environments are completely off in some of them which is frustrating; adjusting the source of lighting would be helpful as well. Lack of transparency adjustment on the colors and no dark color shading equivalent of the highlighter is a bummer; it would be nice to be able to paint things with smooth gradients. There doesn't seem to be a color picker tool either, which makes it hard to resume painting and match properly. Copy & paste would be a very welcome addition as well. More brushes and environments, or the option of allowing user-created content for that, would be awesome. Being able to load textures into brushes would be great. 

I can see this having a lot of utility for design applications once there is more functionality... fingers crossed that they continue going in that direction.

I absolutely love Tilt Brush - it is a must-have for your VR collection and one of the first titles you should buy. Worth every penny.

This is, so far, one of the best experiences you can can have on the Vive if you like to draw or paint or just imagine in a 3D environment.  I can't imagine anyone putting this game on and not getting a few moments of delight from it - very good to show guests how amazing VR can be in a very friendly way.  The very act of drawing in a 3D space is amazing enough to inspire people to want to try it again to draw something new.

The controls are simple and intuitive.  Once you get used to how the very accurate disc controls work on the back of the vive controllers, and how easy they make navigating through countless brush types and sizes, you'll be on your way in no time.  It does take some getting used to but I never thought I was fighting the controls - more like my not understanding how the various brushes and effects worked.  In that sense, I think people will get more out of Tilt Brush the more they put into it.

Great product.  I received this product as a promotion with purchasing it from Amazon.  I'm not going to tag it as receiving the game for free.

25702169.review:
I got this game with my HTC Vive, and it is truly incredible.  It's always one of the first games I launch when I show friends and family VR.  

As a full time Animator, I can say that Tilt Brush is definitely no Photoshop, but I think that people will look back on this program as what started artistic VR "games."  It's funny that I say "I'm going to play Tilt Brush" and not "I'm going to use Tilt Brush," like I would with Photoshop (or GIMP, or Krita).  Part of that may be because you can have any music on in the background, and certain brushes actually react and pulse with the beat!  This makes the experience 10 times better, as gimmicky as it sounds.

They recently added support for loading in obj files and exporting fbx files, which is quite cool.  There is a LOT of potential there.

At the time of writing, Tilt Brush is Windows only, which is a downside for me since I'm moving over to Linux.  I wonder if anyone's got it working with WINE?  

If you didn't get this for free, I would definitely recommend buying it.  It will change the way you think about creating art.

25170586.review:
While there is much fun to be had with Tilt Brush (I really like the music affected brushes!), the huge amount of missing options keeps it from being serious software. I really hope that future updates include:
-layers and groups
-adding/adjusting light sources (location, intensity, diffuse vs. spot, etc.)
-more volumetric or 3D brushes (most of the existing brushes are a flat ribbon type)
-custom brushes
-custom colors/materials (metalic, specular, transparency, etc.)
-spray paint/airbrush
-a real eraser (the current eraser removes entire brush strokes)
-a 3D fill option of some sort, like draw a cube and fill it with a color
-import jpeg, png, bmp to use in your scene (not just reference pics)
-custom background environments

I'm not particularly creative myself, but my mum and my sister are - and they love this app! My sister could probably spend hours in it and not get tired. This app is wonderful and it really adds another dimension to art (literally) and I'm excited to see what not just my family can make but the entire community as well. However, there are some downsides to the app.

As you can see from the screenshots and videos of Tilt Brush, there's no real way to make a "solid" 3D object. All the works of art created are essentially just lines connected together. You can't fill in spaces, everything has to just be line art (but in 3D). This is obviously not a very easy to fix problem - however I had planned on making something like a cityscape but seeing as I won't be able to fill in the walls of the building, I don't think I'll bother. Also, as hard as the team has tried to make the controls intuitive, it can be a little bit confusing. My sister had no problem with it as she's used to new technology - however my mum had a bit of difficulty getting used to the paint pallet and all the tools. But I'm sure if you're looking to get a vive then you're probably used to new technology too and that won't be a problem!

Also, considering this comes free with the vive - there's no reason not to get it!

24183789.review:
Tilt Brush is one of the VR games that I care about the most. It's absolutely one of my favorite VR games, and it is its own completely unique thing. It's not a 3D sculpting game, it is really just drawing in 3D space. I got it for free when I ordered the Vive, but I would definitely have gotten it even it weren't. I recommend it absolutely. I'll use the remaining part of my review to list things that are awesome, flaws and things I feel the game needs. Ranked from most important to least important.

Awesome things:
- The light brush is beautiful and works very well in the default environment
- Embers, snowflakes and stars are some of the really cool brushes that have 3D effects
- The tools like Straight Edge and the Mirror are great
- The mannequin and snowman environments are fun and creative
- Loading a sketch replays the way in which it was drawn, which is really cool to watch
- You can pull in reference images 
- Good updates

[B]This was written many updates ago, several of the following flaws & improvement suggestions may no longer apply[/B]
[i]Flaws:
- Flat brushes look bad from the side and cause anti aliasing issues and cause sharp edges that are difficult to work with. 
- Eraser doesn't erase, it deletes entire strokes. 
- Many of the brushes are gimmicky and frankly bad looking.
- The intro tutorial plays every time you open the game. It's short, but still annoying that you have to wait for the game to show you how to open the left hand palette before you can do it. And you have to clear the sketch to get rid of the actual intro.

Things that would improve the game:
- Ability to move, stretch, scale and re-shape strokes (This would totally invalidate the issue with erasing and flat brushes and would allow for the creation of precise models that are nigh impossible to make at the moment.)
- Better brushes
- A 'pen tool' sort of way to draw, where you place points and then bend the curve between them
- A way to move up and down
- No limit to teleportation (Yes, anti aliasing at long distances is a problem but I think it should be the user's problem)
- Multiple mirrors! I want to draw in a 3D kaleidoscope!
- More environments (Although I feel that the light brush in a dark empty space is iconic to Tilt Brush at this point)[/i]

23604034.review:
Tiltbrush is very good, but there are a few flaws. The most prominent flaw is, when you start making a line with a flat brush for example, the first inch or so it wont "paint". Even if you use the straight edge tool. So its very hard to align it. There also should be an option to lock the flat brush in the orientation that it's in relative to the controller (for example, in a way that if you pull the brush upwards, the brush creates a thin line, and sideways for a fat line). As of right now, the brush "swivels" on the controller like a wheel on a shopping cart. It turns to the direction you are pulling the brush in. 
More brushes also wouldnt hurt, and a flat plane tool so you could paint flat, similiar to a canvas (would be useful for painting walls to buildings for example).

Pros: Came for free in my bundle. It's simple and easy to pick up. Not entirely sure if it's worth the pricetag if you have to buy it, but if you're an imaginative and creative person, i think you'll like it.
Cons: More tools and more options wouldnt hurt.

23334222.review:
(recieved this game for free with my vive purchase but would've bought this full price if it wasn't)

As someone who always loved to make his own maps in map editors for some of my favorite games,
loved to make silly sculptures out of clay when i was a kid.
But sucked at things like drawing.
This program is a gamechanger.
Drawing on paper or with a mouse on pc never was my strong point as the lines i try to drawn are never how i want them.
But in tiltbrush...
trying to draw in 3d is just awesome.
The drawing part is arguably harder as you draw in midair without any support for your arm.
But one simple button and you delete the last brushstroke and go on to get the right one.
The first time you try tiltbrush you're probably gonna draw a flower or a pen is. 
But don't stop there xD 
Keep trying to make something cool and you will !
Start by getting a feel for which brushes you can use for certain objects/ situations how they look and what color looks great on them.
Try and work with mirrormode as it is a extremely usefull tool and helps alot to get some symmetry
Look at some of the artwork of other people and see how they used certain brushes/ effects.
I did most of my earliest drawings by reference since like i said drawing isn't my strong point.
But after a few drawings i got the inspiration to try and make something original.
Keep trying and you will get results that leave you with a hard feeling of satisfaction ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

Now gentlemen,
Start drawing those waifus

23207552.review:
This came with my Vive.
I had seen some videos and thought it was pretty neat, even though I was a little put off by the gaudy neon stuff.
Decided there was nothing stopping me from giving it a try. If nothing else, at least I could have a look at what other people have drawn, right?

Wow.

Just wow.

So glad I tried it. It's spectacular. I'm not much of an artist, but this unleashed my creativity like nothing I've ever tried before.

I've been planning to build a game, and I have some rough prototypes in Unity, but I've always found it hard to translate my level design ideas into actual level geometry as problems always crop up. From now on, Tilt Brush is likely the step between "idea" and "building the level", as I can quickly sketch out my ideas **IN 3D** so I can solve problems as if there was a save button on my imagination.

Amazing. Keep in mind that you don't have to draw in gaudy light streamers if you don't want to, but they look WAY better in VR than they do in screenshots. I think I get it now.

With the addition of quick undo (press left side of left touch pad), it became even easier.  Wow, just wow.

Don't know if it's worth the price tag, as I never had to make that call, but I think it is.
At least give it a try. You'll be glad you did.

Pros : This has been a fun way to show off the system to people who want to check it out. Using it solo is promising. It is a blast to tab out to refference material in a browser while listening to pandora. Was really able to lose myself for a bit.

Cons : For me, most of Tilt Brush's appeal comes from simply being on the Vive. Tilt Brush sort of demos the possibilities of expressing yourself artistically in VR with only the very basic functions. I was left wanting a more robust tool set, and maybe a more accurate way to see where a stroke will start or end.

Overall: The price is steep. Had it not come with the Vive, I would feel pretty let down had I paid 30$ for it. Maybe it will have more practical functions later, and I will try more. The promise is there and as it stands it is truely unique experience and I will reccomend it on that alone. However, it is hard to want to return to it when I know that some pretty basic artistic visions are not going to be able to be fulfilled in it's current state.

22885462.review:
Tilt Brush est un logiciel remarquable sur de nombreux points, particulièrement aujourd'hui où la réalité virtuelle n'en est qu'à ses débuts.
Tout d'abord, l'interface est très bien pensée, et c'est d'ailleurs pour cela que cette application a été encensée à ses débuts. Pas de menu flottant ou d'écran plat virtuel collé au visage, la manipulation de la "palette" virtuelle est très intuitive et profite de la facilité d'utilisation des manettes du Vive. Le retour haptique des manettes est agréable et offre une sensation de matérialité bienvenue, surtout lorsqu'on fait défiler les différents menus à l'aide du trackpad.

Le concept en lui-même est relativement simple : j'ai souvent entendu Tilt Brush être qualifié de "Paint pour la RV". C'est à peu près ça. Dessiner et peindre dans l'espace offre une réelle sensation de liberté et d'immersion tout en utilisant les caractéristiques propres de la RV, on ne peut pas imaginer ce programme sur un écran classique.

Les brosses sont agréablement variées, mais on ne refuserait pas d'en avoir encore plus. Mes préférées sont, comme beaucoup, la lumière et le papier. Le papier, justement, offre une sensation de création matérielle, encore plus qu'avec les autres brosses. La lumière, quant à elle, propose une sensation un peu surréelle, à mi-chemin entre la magie et la sf.
D'autres brosses sont amusantes à utiliser, comme la neige ou "l'hypercolor" mais ne me servent pas autant que les deux premières.

Des outils comme le miroir ou celui permettant de tracer des lignes droites sont vraiment utiles et pratiques, avec toujours une utilisation simple et compréhensible, et cela nous mène à une autre qualité de Tilt Brush : son accessibilité.
Toutes les personnes de mon entourage qui ont pu tester Tilt Brush n'ont eu aucun mal à évoluer dans l'espace et à utiliser l'interface, même s'ils n'avaient jamais essayé la RV. La plupart n'ayant pas de pratique artistique, leurs créations n'étaient peut-être pas forcément impressionnantes, mais elles ont su s'amuser en occupant l'espace à coups de lumières, de couleurs et de textures. Je pense cependant que posséder une pratique artistique comme le dessin ou même des réalisations en trois dimensions aide vraiment à s'approprier le logiciel.

Car oui, Tilt Brush possède cependant quelques limites. Comme toute application faisant appel à des compétences de création, si, justement, on ne possède pas ce genre de compétences, une fois la nouveauté passée et une fois que les gribouillis volants n'amusent plus, un vide doit se faire sentir. Ayant un peu de pratique de mon côté, je ne peux pas parler en connaissance de cause mais il me semble que c'est une situation à envisager.
De plus, certains fonctionnalités semblent manquer. Par exemple, une fonction de mise à l'échelle serait bienvenue (la fonction de téléportation venant d'être ajoutée récemment)

En conclusion, même si je l'ai obtenu gratuitement par la précommande de mon Vive, je ne peux que le recommander puisque que je l'aurais sans doute acheté de toute manière. C'est une expérience immersive et libératrice. D'autres applications pour le logiciel pourraient être envisagées : il pourrait permettre à toute sorte de designers ou de créateurs de faire des ébauches rapides de créations, d'idées, de projets. Un carnet de brouillon en réalité virtuelle. Il y a sûrement beaucoup d'autres possibilités et j'espère que Tilt Brush sera mis à jour et deviendra encore meilleur et plus peaufiné. Si ce n'est pas lui, ce sera un autre, en tout cas espèrons-le.

22803695.review:
I found my new canvas. I've dreamt about this since I was a kid. I've had this creative urge to draw and paint in 3D space for years, but only achieved it through post-processing with video editing software and more recently with tracking technology like Leap Motion in VR. So I've been waiting all this time for something that didn't even exist, and here it is. Talk about scratching an itch! I've followed Tilt Brush progress since they first posted a concept video on Youtube a few years back. The approach  was a little different, using virtual flat surfaces you could paint on and rotate to create 3D objects and scenery. And that was good enough for me. I sat around practicing, air-painting if you will, to make sure I was ready to use it when it arrived. It has come a far way since then. The perfectly tracked HTC Vive controllers are a joy to use and having one controller as "an artist's toolset" is a great addition and very intuitive. I can't picture myself working without it. I would be happy just to draw, but Tilt Brush features loads of effects and helping tools you can use to expand your creative experience. I was testing the mirror tool that lets you draw in perfect symmetry, and I accidentally made it spin on its own axis. I had no idea that was possible. With it I can easily create galaxies in space, awesome projectile effects or trippy tornadoes. I can't wait to see what other features that will be added in the future. There has already been a pretty big update adding new paint brushes and effects, making the experience easier and more interesting. It will force you to think differently. You might have to relive your early days using a pen or brush on paper, getting to know a new artform all over again, but you will have a great time doing it. Which is what Tilt Brush is. Pure creative fun. My humblest gratitude to the makers of Tilt Brush and Google for making a life-long dream come true. 

10/10 would tilt again.

22294832.review:
Last July, I went to the first stop of the HTC Vive Live truck tour in San Diego.  I expected to try out a virtual reality headset and either be unimpressed or think it was kind of cool.  Then they loaded up Tilt Brush as my second demo and I could paint and actually see depth as I painted in three dimensions.  This was a huge deal to me as I can't see 3D in movies or in those magic frame pictures that require you to be able to see 3D to appreciate.

I drew some flowers that day and signed a letter E for the first initial of my name.

Six months later I got to draw a purple monster that started out as a hut and ended up looking like a Pac-Man ghost in front of Skillman and Hackett at the Steam VR Developer Showcase.  It was a pivotal moment in my life where I could thank the creators personally for one of the most remarkable art applications available on the market.

Despite the sappy emotional story, I encourage everyone at any age to pick up the Vive controllers and create something in Tilt Brush.  I can't wait to see what fellow Vive owners and their friends come up with now that it is commercially available!

Ich selbst bin künstlerisch nicht wirklich begabt, aber was man hier in die virtuelle Welt pinselt, sieht einfach gut aus und macht auch noch spaß. Die Steuerung der Farbpalette, zufügen von Effekten, skallieren der Größe, alles läuft intuitiv und ist sehr gut durchdacht.
Natürlich wirken knapp 20,- Euro für ein Malprogramm auf den ersten Blick zu teuer, aber wenn man 1x angefangen hat seiner Phantasie freien lauf zu lassen und ein eigenes Kunstwerk um sich herum entstehen sieht, weiss man, warum man es gekauft hat.
Das Programm lief auch mit einer GTX 970 ausgezeichnet und machte keinerlei Zicken irgendwelcher Art.
Für mich eine klare Kaufempfehlung für alle kreativen Köpfe und die, die es sein wollen.
Gruß Ziffi

Yes it did after all work on Windows Mixed Reality but do require minimum hardware requirements to work at all. 
I baught it in hope the first time using GTX1050 on  a i5 3500 CPU. It didnt work or semi worked- It loaded the handcontrollers, but that was all.  I knew the risk and thankfully I could be refunded by steam, great and many thanks, it do make it easier to buy software knowing if it doesn't work you get your money back ☼
Now I realised that the performance could be an issue so i sold my old computer and upgraded to a GTX1060 OC on an  I7 4770. Now everything works as a charm and Tilt Brush is a lot of fun for the whole family. Either you are Artistic or Constructive. It is an awesome software and a must have in your VR library . 
What I yet have to find out or make a request for in the software is surfaces. A fill tool, or making filled areas so one could create walls, ceilings and floors and even different "room" shapes in combination with the painting tools. Much like the environment option, I would love to add lighting environment just as you do in a movie setting. Hi temperature (Kelvin) lights in mid day to low temp for evening and traced shadows.  If not in this applikation perhaps in a compatible one to exchange creations. 
Painting in true 3D make you curios to expand that creative universe even further.
